title: Heterospathe
text:
Heterospathe is a <a href="monoecious">monoecious</a> <a href="genus">genus</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a> in the <a href="arecaceae">palm</a> family found in <a href="Oceania">Oceania</a>, where it is called sagisi palm. With 39 <a href="species">species</a>, "Heterospathe" is named from a <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a> combination of "various" and "spathe", which describes the two distinct bract types.
Description.
They exhibit considerable variation in morphology and habit; the slender trunks may be solitary or sparsely to densely clustering, some are miniatures and perpetual undergrowth subjects while others contribute to the canopy top. The trunks are ringed by leaf scars and end in a poorly defined or absent <a href="crownshaft">crownshaft</a>. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are usually <a href="pinnate">pinnate</a>, rarely bifid, from small to large, and frequently red colored when new.
The <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a> is interfoliar but will hang pendent nearing antithesis. It may be branched from one to four orders with short white to yellow branches of spirally arranged, male and female <a href="flower">flower</a>s. Ellipsoidal to spherical, the <a href="fruit">fruit</a> ripen to various shades of orange and red and contain a single <a href="seed">seed</a>.
Distribution and habitat.
"Heterospathe" species are relatively widespread across the <a href="Pacific">Pacific's</a> western edges with several in <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a>, the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>, the <a href="Solomon%20Islands">Solomon Islands</a>, eastern <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> and <a href="Micronesia">Micronesia</a>. Across this range they inhabit <a href="montane">montane</a> and lowland <a href="rain%20forest">rain forest</a>, in some cases receiving total shade or filtered <a href="light">light</a> while others mature into full sun with age; "H. delicatula" and "H. humilis" are found at high elevations in New Guinea's mountains. Being rain forest dwellers they are typically found in <a href="humus">humus</a>-rich soil.
Cultivation and uses.
The colorful new foliage has increased their popularity in <a href="Australia">Australia</a> though they are still uncommon there and more so in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> where only one species is cultivated with any regularity. In any case, they naturally prefer surroundings resembling those in their range, particularly acidic <a href="soil">soil</a> which is fast-draining, copious <a href="water">water</a> and protection from cold. The petioles and leaflets are woven and thatched, the <a href="Heart%20of%20palm">palm heart</a> is reportedly eaten, and fruit from "H. elata" is chewed as a <a href="Betel%20nut">betel</a> substitute.
